instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message: Gday guys I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that was liquid damaged and would not turn on and had corrosion all around <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>, short on LCD connecter. after these few components were replaced I now get a chime and it now boots into OSX. the problem I'm having is the fan stays on high after about 1 minute and everything is loading very slow. could someone please assist me with a link to 3s156 as I'm having trouble locating the file. any assistance would be gratefully appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message:
First of all try known good trackpad board/flex.
Get 3S156 ASD EFI version here.
[url]https://drive.google.com/open?id=1QWuvVuIU-k8Cyur23Gxf_2IJmo5TxoVb[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message: Here are the results from ASD

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message: Thanks mate, i changed to a good trackpad flex. this is not the issue but thanks for the file. its coming up with sensor issues in ASD so ill start looking around sensor voltage divider etc. any further assistance would be appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message:
VP0R is PBUS sensor.
Poste exact voltage for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL>:
Check for corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR>.

Finstack sensor is on LIO board.
Try known good LIO board/flex.
Also check for corrosion at J9500.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.56v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> 0.166v
<TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> looks clean
i have many IO boards so will swap out
J9500 is clean, all pins are in tact and solid.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message:
First, use new post to reply; the comments are not easy visible if the thread will go ahead in more pages.

"<SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> 0.166v"
That's no good; should be aprox 2.5V for 60W charger.
Post <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message:
ive been using a lab PSU for many years now. i always set it to 18.5v 
<TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> P1 GND@0v P2 3.43v P3 8.53v P4 8.54v P5 Fluccuates between 3.42 & 3.5v P6 0v

Thank You.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message:
Mate this machine almost owned me. are you saying <SIGNAL>SMC_PBUS_VSENSE</SIGNAL> 0.166v is correct?

i already checked <RESISTOR>R5503</RESISTOR>/04 and <CAPACITOR>C5504</CAPACITOR> last night and they were correct. im sorry to be a fucktard but i put the IO flex under the scope and there was a cockroach pube inside it. i swapped the IO board out as well and done another ASD scan and it came back clear. from a logical point of view i guess this would be correct though. Im installing High Sierra now and will report back if this job is done. Thank you so much mate. now i have another 9 similar boards to look at.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible sensor fail
threads.message: it appears that pubic hairs from cockroaches can cause a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> to run like shit. this job is done thanks.
